template: {instruction} USER QUERY: {query} nBACKGROUND INFORMATION ON PHISHING: Check the sender's email address for small spelling errors. Avoid clicking on links in emails you're unsure about. Instead, visit the official website directly. Be cautious with emails that create urgency or ask for sensitive information. Trustworthy senders usually have official and error-free email addresses. Unusual characters or spelling mistakes in the username are often signs of phishing. Your browser can block known phishing sites and warn you about potential threats. This feature provides an extra layer of protection and works by using blacklists or whitelists of websites. It’s recommended to keep this feature enabled at all times for your safety. Use two-factor authentication (2FA) whenever possible. Keep your software and antivirus up to date. Be cautious with unsolicited emails or links. Complex and unique passwords make it harder for attackers to access your account. Reusing the same password puts multiple accounts at risk during a phishing attack. Tactics Information: Phishing involves pretending to be a trusted entity to steal your sensitive information, often via email or fake websites. Phishing is a type of cyber attack where attackers trick you into revealing sensitive information, like passwords or credit card details. Phishing attackers use tactics like creating urgency, pretending to be an authority figure, or manipulating emotions like fear or greed. Common phishing tactics include urgency ('Act now or your account will be closed!'), authority ('This is your CEO speaking'), and fake links or emails designed to steal information. Urgency is a tactic where attackers pressure you to act quickly, like 'Your account will be locked in 24 hours.' This is designed to make you act without thinking. Always verify before responding. Authority is a tactic where attackers pretend to be someone important, like your boss or a government official, to make you comply without questioning. Be cautious of unusual requests, even if they appear to come from someone you trust. Emotional manipulation uses fear ('Your account has been compromised') or greed ('You’ve won $1,000!') to trick you. Always verify such claims before acting. Phishing links often include numbers or spelling mistakes to mimic real domains. Hover over the link to check the address before clicking. Tactics Technical Information: Technical phishing methods include techniques like Hijacking, DNS Spoofing, and Content Spoofing. Each of these methods exploits technical vulnerabilities to deceive users. Let me know if you want me to explain any of them in detail! Hijacking refers to intercepting user sessions or traffic to steal information or impersonate the user. For example, session hijacking occurs when attackers take over a user's session by stealing session cookies. Learn more: Hijacking Overview DNS spoofing is a method where attackers manipulate DNS records to redirect users to fraudulent websites, making them think they are visiting a legitimate site. Learn more: DNS Spoofing Details Content spoofing involves altering legitimate website content to deceive users, often by embedding malicious scripts or links. Learn more: Content Spoofing Details
